Civic Rhymeline Bureau

Championship knit strategy. Platinum boy-band routing. Full-spectrum interpretive dispatch.

We were chartered when the city choir lost its voice in sleet, and needed hands to send instructions with a heel-and-hollow beat. Our director, Needle Marshal Mirelle Quince, won three national knit crowns, then took five velvet-jacket singers from garage gigs to civic renown.

Every memo here is danced, every clause and date must rhyme, every tour and yarn brigade runs punctual as station time.

Chapter One | The Platform at Frostline Station

Where Orders Travel by Shoulder and Spine

At dawn, the knit floor hummed like rails. Mirelle stood between cone yarn towers, tapping pattern hooks against a brass rail while the boys rehearsed in silent hours. No shouted counts, no printed chart. The body spoke; the body signed. A turn of wrist meant "hold for storm," a lifted chin meant "change the line."
